Authors: Schleich, J; Klobasa, M; Golz, S; Brunner, M
document title: Effects of feedback on residential electricity demand-Findings from a field trial in Austria
abstract: This paper analyzes the effects of providing feedback on electricity consumption in a field trial involving more than 1500 households in Linz, Austria. About half of these households received feedback together with information about electricity-saving measures (pilot group), while the remaining households served as a control group. Participation in the pilot group was random, but households were able to choose between two types of feedback: access to a web portal or written feedback by post. Results from cross section OLS regression suggest that feedback provided to the pilot group corresponds with electricity savings of around 4.5% for the average household. Our results from quantile regressions imply that for households in the 30th to the 70th percentile of electricity consumption, feedback on electricity consumption is statistically significant and effects are highest in absolute terms and as a share of electricity consumption. For percentiles below or above this range, feedback appears to have no effect. Finally, controlling for a potential endogeneity bias induced by non random participation in the feedback type groups, we find no difference in the effects of feedback provided via the web portal and by post. (C) 2013 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Notes: Doc level: Important point of the study: households are allowed to choose the medium of the feedback - wed based or mail - and there is no difference in the effect size. Thus medium does not seem to matter if there is a choice. Difficult to capture this trial in the current framework. ; Allowing choice of feedback means treatments are not assigned randomly. However the allocation between treatment and control is somewhat random (still depends on whether those selected for pilot are reflecting overall population).; practice set - come back if time allows for it

Authors: Strapp, C
document title: Ontario Energy Board Smart Price Pilot Final Report. Prepared by IBM Global Business Services and eMeter Strategic Consulting for the Ontario Energy Board
abstract:
In June 2006, the Ontario Energy Board (the Board) initiated the Ontario Energy
Board Smart Price Pilot (OSPP) project to test the reactions and impacts on
consumer behaviour of different time-sensitive price structures. By August 1, 2006,
375 of Hydro Ottawa’s electricity customers had been placed into one of three pricing
groups and were receiving monthly Electricity Usage Statements in addition to their
bi-monthly electricity bills.
The OSPP was operated until February 28, 2007 with the intent to assess:
■ The extent to which various time-sensitive pricing structures cause a shift of
electricity consumption to off-peak periods as measured by the reduction in peak
demand
■ The extent to which each price structure causes a change in total monthly
consumption.
■ The understandability of and acceptability by residential consumers of each
pricing structure and the communications associated with each.
Results of the OSPP were measured through the quantitative analysis of demand
response, total energy conservation, and participant survey responses. Qualitative
feedback was garnered from focus groups and tracking of participant support calls.

Authors: Li, Rui; Fang, Debin; Xu, Jiajun
document title: Does China's carbon inclusion policy promote household carbon emissions reduction? Theoretical mechanisms and empirical evidence
abstract: China’s carbon inclusion policy (CIP) is an innovative voluntary emission reduction mechanism that aims to drive consumption-side emission reductions and achieve dual carbon goals. However, the effectiveness of the policy has not yet been assessed. To fill this research gap, this study evaluated the impact of CIP on urban household carbon emissions based on panel data from 283 cities in China from 2006 to 2020. This was conducted using staggered difference-in-differences (DID), synthetic DID, and spatial DID methods. The results showed that the CIP significantly reduced household carbon emissions through the green consumption awareness enhancing effect and green supply capacity improving effect. Heterogeneity tests indicated that carbon reduction effects are stronger in electricity and gas consumption and relatively modest in the heating and transportation domains. Cities with higher financial technology levels and greater government intervention had better policy outcomes. CIP also exhibited spatial spillover effects on household carbon emissions and synergistically reduced air pollution. Despite incurring certain economic costs, it ultimately promoted regional economic growth. This study can provide theoretical and empirical evidence for China to promote CIP and achieve its dual carbon goals.
Notes: Coefficient: The coefficient is of the HH emissions from gas consumption
Notes: Sample size: The authors haven't provided the sample size anywhere in the paper. And the total sample size has been reported based on the obs column in Table 2 Page 7
Notes: Doc level:
1. Throughout the paper, the authors are talking about the total HH carbon emissions which is the total sum of HH electricity related carbon emissions, HH gas related carbon emissions, carbon emissions generated from HH transportation, and carbon emissions from HH heating. The authors mentioned that the calculations are directly related to the residents' living consumption.
2. The authors haven't made clear in the paper on the number of HHs in treatment and control groups.
Notes: Study scope: The research sample for this study consisted of panel data from 283 cities across China, spanning the years 2006 to 2020
Notes_Biases: The study has three models to analyse the effects - Staggered DID model, Synthetic DID model, Spatial DID model
Notes_interventionDuration: The study doesn't clearly provide the specifics on the intervention duration. It just provides info that the CIP policy was started in 2015 in one province and the in the next province the policy was started in 2018
medium: awareness campaigns in the residential neighbourhoods
Notes_interventionType:
The CIP has three measures:
1. Policy encouragement through awareness campaigns
2. A commercial incentive mechanism which includes establishing low carbon business alliances and formulating financial and fiscial policies to promote CIP systems
3. A quantification and verification system for CIP emission reduction actions and a trading mechanism
issuesToResolve: Need to check the if the emissions component can be included or not

Authors: Park, Jiyong; Moon, Hyung Bin; Jin, Taeyoung
document title: The impact of adopting an energy information system on household energy consumption: a dyanic difference-in-differences approach
abstract: This study analyzes effects of adopting an energy information system on energy use based on the advanced metering infrastructure (AMI) in South Korea. Adopting the AMI was randomly assigned by the Korean Government. However, the adoption timing varies across household, making it difficult to apply an ordinary difference-in-difference (DID) approach to measure the impact, given the variation in adoption timing across households. We use a dynamic DID that is suitable for estimating a causal effect of a policy whose treatment timing differs depending upon the individual. Results indicate that AMI adoption led to a reduction in household electricity consumption, peaking within 18 months after adoption with a slight rebound effect. Our findings suggest that providing information on energy consumption and cost in the household sector can significantly reduce electricity use by as much as one quarter of average monthly consumption. Reducing electricity use in households can be achieved in several ways, including monetary incentives as well as personal and social feedback provided by adopting the AMI, implying the importance of a dissemination policy.
Notes: Coefficient: The coefficient of when the treatment started
Notes: Difference of means: In this case, the mean and SD for both the control and treatment group has been provided. However the mean and SD for the treatment group has been provided in two - before treatment and after treatment. Here I have included the mean and SD for the control group and the mean and SD for the treatment group - after treatment.
Notes: Sample size: The authors started by saying that the sample includes 78181 HHs. However they went and explained that they excluded HHs with missing data or monthly consumption exceeding 1MWh for a balanced panel. And the total sample became 20,047
Notes: Significance: Not enough information is provided about the significance and tests in the paper. Also there seems to be an error when reporting the standard errors in the paper in Table 3. They are calling it P-value.
Notes: Study scope: In the paper, the research was undertaken for South Korean HHs who installed AMIs in 2019
Notes_Biases: The study is using a dynamic DID model and the authors haven't clearly defined the controls and other variables.
Notes_interventionDuration: The study has a policy component which was implemented by the govt and it went on after this study. However the authors only analysed the policy component for two years.
medium: The AMIs were installed on a voluntary basis
Notes_interventionType: The intervention was the installation of AMI - Advanced Metering Infrastructure that offers consumers real time electricity consumption data and cost information.

Authors: Wendt, Charlotte; Kosin, Dominick; Adam, Martin; Benlian, Alexander
document title: Sustainable Energy consumption behaviour with smart meters: The role of relative performance and evaluative standards
abstract: The growing adoption of smart meters enables the measurement of households' energy consumption, influenced not solely by building characteristics such as thermal insulation but also by residents' behavioural patterns, such as heating and ventilation practices. To motivate residents to adopt more sustainable behaviours, user interfaces on smartphones and laptops are increasingly using consumption data from households' smart meters to enable effective goal-setting. In contrast to previous research largely focusing on goal-setting in isolation, this study examines the role of specific social comparison-related design features that future research and practitioners can consider along with goal-setting to stimulate sustainable behaviours. Specifically, we look into the influence of residents' perception of their relative performance (i.e., whether their behaviour was better or worse than a reference group) on their ambition to act (i.e., targeted inprovement goal) and their actual energy consumption behaviour. Moreover, we investigate the influence of a goal's evaluative standard (i.e., whether the goal refers to one's own or other's perforrmance) on the relationship between relative performance, ambition to act, and energy consumption behaviour. Drawing on social consumption theory, we conducted a framed field experiment with 152 households. We find that a goal's evaluative standard influences resident's awareness of their relative performance, affecting their ambition to act and, ultimately, their energy consumption behaviour. More specifically, we find that whereas other- (vs. self-) referencing goals encourage residents from worse-than-average performing households more strongly to improve their energy consumption behaviour, they discourage better-than-average ones. Overall, our study provides novel insights into the interplay between relative performance and evaluative standards as a means of fostering social comparison in smart meter-facilitated goal-setting, highlighting their crucial role in effectively supporting sustainable behaviours.
Notes: Coefficient: The dependent variable is heating intensity reduction. And this is the coefficient for Stage 1 of Relative Performance which include all the control variables
Notes: Difference of means: The mean and SD for the control group is available in the Appendix. But the mean and SD of the treatment group is not in line with how the results for the coefficient has been presented, that's why I haven't included them here
Notes: Sample size: The authors recruited 192 participants and removed 40 for three reasons, there 152 participants in the treatment group. The number for the control group is mentioned in the Appendix.
Notes: Doc level: The dependent variable is the heating intensity reduction, which is measured by household's self reported heating behaviour using several seven point Likert-type scale items. Authors computed each HHs heating intensity by calculating the mean of the items for self-reported behaviour.
Notes: Study scope: In the paper, the authors mentioned that they chose participants from Germany by recruiting participants from the crowdsourcing platform Prolific but they didn't mention anything about the region
Notes_Biases: The study was conducted using a 2x2 (relative performance; evaluative standard of the goal) framed field experiment. The authors defined framed field experiments as something which uses a sample of real subjects in actual settings where participants make real life decisions related to the study.
Notes_interventionDuration: The study mentions that the data was collected from Jan to Feb 2021. However it also mention this - we asked participants to briefly report their on their HHs current heating behaviour after 2 weeks before inviting participants to the final reporting round after 4 weeks.
medium: awareness and instructions followed by self-reporting from the HHs
Notes_interventionType: Six stages of experimental procedure - offered participants a context of the study; participants reported their own HHs heating behaviour of the past two weeks; Participants were categorised into the group of HHs with either worse or better than average RP; randomly assigned participants to a condition that offered a goal setting functionality; Participants reported on their HHs current heating behaviour; Provided feedback to the participants on their goal attainment

abstract: The growing adoption of smart meters enables the measurement of households' energy consumption, influenced not solely by building characteristics such as thermal insulation but also by residents' behavioural patterns, such as heating and ventilation pract
Notes: Coefficient: The dependent variable is heating intensity reduction. And this is the coefficient for Stage 3 of Relative Performance where authors analysed the mediating influence of ambition to act
Notes: Difference of means: The mean and SD for the control group is available in the Appendix. But the mean and SD of the treatment group is not in line with how the results for the coefficient has been presented, that's why I haven't included them here
Notes: Sample size: The authors recruited 192 participants and removed 40 for three reasons, there 152 participants in the treatment group. The number for the control group is mentioned in the Appendix.
Notes: Doc level: The dependent variable is the heating intensity reduction, which is measured by household's self reported heating behaviour using several seven point Likert-type scale items. Authors computed each HHs heating intensity by calculating the mean of the items
Notes: Study scope: In the paper, the authors mentioned that they chose participants from Germany by recruiting participants from the crowdsourcing platform Prolific but they didn't mention anything about the region
Notes_Biases: The study was conducted using a 2x2 (relative performance; evaluative standard of the goal) framed field experiment. The authors defined framed field experiments as something which uses a sample of real subjects in actual settings where participants make
Notes_interventionDuration: The study mentions that the data was collected from Jan to Feb 2021. However it also mention this - we asked participants to briefly report their on their HHs current heating behaviour after 2 weeks before inviting participants to the final reporting roun
medium: awareness and instructions followed by self-reporting from the HHs
Notes_interventionType: Six stages of experimental procedure - offered participants a context of the study; participants reported their own HHs heating behaviour of the past two weeks; Participants were categorised into the group of HHs with either worse or better than average R

Authors: Cabrera D; Lambert C; Naef P; Bertholet J L; Patel M K
document title: Beyond short-term savings: A ten-year analysis of energy efficiency program outcomes in swiss househols
abstract: This paper investigates the enduring impacts of Swiss energy efficiency programs on household electricity use and on the continuation of energy-conserving practices. Employing a mixed-methods research design, we  analyzed electricity consumption data from 2009 to 2019 and incorporated insights from 2840 survey responses collected in 2018. Findings reveal sustained reductions in electricity use and continued adoption of energyefficient appliances among program participants, underscoring the role of non-financial incentives—particularly environmental awareness—in promoting long-lasting energy conservation behaviors. Socio-cultural factors emerged as more indicative of household energy use than social status. Scaling the results to the national level, we estimate a potential annual energy saving of 2400 GWh, equivalent to 13 % of Swiss household electricity consumption in 2009. The paper advocates energy policies that prioritize engagement and periodic reinforce ment to enhance long-term program efficacy.
Notes: Coefficient: This coefficient is based on a linear model to assess the relation between electricity consumption reduction and participation in Ecosocial program only
Notes_baselineConsumption: The values for the baseline consumption is not provided but in Fig 10, average electricity consumption has been scale to 100
Notes: Difference of means: The mean and SD for the control and treatment group hasn't been provided clearly. The estimated coefficient is the mean electricity decrease 2009/2019 in perspective of program participation and it is estimated from the linear model presented in the Appendix
Notes: Sample size: The details for the sample size for program wise participation is presented in Table 1 on page 5
Notes: Doc level: The paper has many tables depicting the changes in the electricity consumption but they are based on certain key questions from the survey questionnaire and not program-wise difference
Notes: Study scope: The study is based in the caton of Geneva, Switzerland and the authors have analyzed the three efficiency programs - DoublEco, ActivEco, and Ecosocial - all under the umbrella of Eco21 that was launched in 2007
Notes_Biases: The approach of the study is based on a survey (2840) coupled with the historic annual consumption of electricity (2005-2019) of a sample
Notes_interventionDuration: The study analyzed the effect of three efficiency programs from 2009-2019. That's why I have kept the number of weeks to 520 since the program is the treatment here and has been running since 2009 till the study was undertaken.
Notes_interventionType: Ecosocial - A home visit by energy ambassadors lasting 45 min to 2 h, HHs receive advice and energy efficient devices - efficient lamps, LED lightbulbs, an electric kettle boiler, a voucher for A++ to A+++ fridges/freezers to decrease their consumption

Authors: Liu, Ning; Luo Xi; Liu Xiaojun; Xing Menglin
document title: Impacts of Normative information on college students' energy saving intentions and behaviours in the dormitory
abstract: College students’ energy-saving behaviors in dormitory buildings are crucial for reducing energy consumption on university campuses. An information framework aimed at normalization can do well in motivating individuals’ energy-saving behaviors. To assess the effectiveness of normative information intervention strategies in motivating college students to save energy, this study innovatively adopts a new method combining traditional influence path analysis and field experiment, which makes up for the shortcomings of the traditional single questionnaire survey method. First, this study introduced “normative information” and “personal norms” into the theory of planned behavior (TPB). The aim was to explore the mechanisms by which the provision of normative information affects college students’ energy-saving intentions through a questionnaire (352 questionnaires). Then, on this basis, a field experiment was conducted in 70 university dormitories with 313 students to further assess the effectiveness of four normative information intervention strategies in promoting energy-saving behaviors. The study results showed: 1) Attitude, perceived behavioral control, subjective norms, and personal norms were significantly correlated with energy saving intentions. 2) Positive normative feedback and low-intensity normative feedback had significant positive effects on personal norms, which fully mediated the relationships between positive/low-intensity normative feedback and energy-saving intentions. 3) Positive low-intensity normative information achieved the best energy-saving effect (with an energy-saving ratio of 29.18%), followed by positive high-intensity normative information (24.97%) and negative low-intensity normative information (24.38%). The results can provide reference for reducing dormitory energy consumption.
Notes: Coefficient: The coefficient of the cross-product term ni*t represented the estimated value of the DID model, i.e., the change in the electricity consumption of an experimental group relative to the control grpup. This value is for Group 1 where the nomative information was - Positive high-intensity
Notes_baselineConsumption: This is the baseline average electricity consumption for Group 1
Notes: Sample size: A total of 313 students from 70 dormitories were recruited. The dormitories were randomized into 5 groups - control group and 4 experimental group. Each group included 14 dormitories. However in the paper, a clear distinction between the number of students in each group hasn't been provided
Notes: Study scope: The field experiment was implemented in student dormitories at a university in Xi'an, China
Notes_interventionDuration: The intervention period consisted of two parts - baseline period and experimental period. Baseline period was the intervention period and only collection of electricity consumption data was done and experimental period lasted 4 weeks during which differentiated normative information interventions were carried out and also the collection of electricity consumption data
Notes_interventionType: The experimental period lasted for four weeks. During this time, the experimentars provided normative information to the dormitories of each experimental group at 10AM every Monday and data regarding each dormitory's electricity consumption were uniformly collected at 20:00 every Sunday.

Authors: Ta, Chi L.
document title: Do conservative contests work? An analysis of a large-scale energy competitive rebate program
abstract:
Contests are widely used as mechanisms to incentivize efforts in various contexts, from research 
innovation to athletic and employee performance. This paper builds an analytical model and 
provides empirical evidence to assess the effectiveness of a large-scale, real-world residential 
energy conservation contest in Vietnam. The model suggests that contests offering multiple prizes 
and requiring a minimum amount of effort can effectively promote conservation. It also identifies 
factors that influence the conservation effort, such as the cost of effort, size of prizes, and types of 
contestants. To empirically estimate the effect of the energy conservation contest, this paper uses 
a unique confidential dataset of monthly residential electricity usage with over 45 million ob
servations. The results indicate that the contest significantly reduced electricity consumption 
among contestants, and the effect of the contest could persist for months after its conclusion, 
leading to an average abatement cost of $27 per ton of CO2 emissions.
dependent_variable: Logged Electricity Consumption of HH i at time t
Notes: Coefficient: This coefficient does not include any control variable
Notes_baselineConsumption: The baseline information is not available but the summary statistics is avaiable where one can see the mean, sd, min, and max
Notes: Difference of means: The author has used the standard difference-in-difference estimation framework to estimate the competitive rebate program's ITT effect.
Notes: Sample size: The author hasn't provided the clear number of the HHs but has this information: the primary dataset is panel data of monthly electricity billing records from 27 district service territories from Jan 2012 to Dec 2017.
Notes: Doc level: The objective of the study is to investigate the efficacy of an electricity conservation contest that awards prizes to HHs for surpassing a minimum conservation requirement. Participation in the contest was voluntary but it was only available in certain districts at different times. The author assumes that conditional on the inclusion of HH-time fixed effects and controls for time-variant district characteristics, the timing of the contest roll-out was plausibly exogenous
Notes: Significance: The paper reports that the estimated coefficients for the post-treatment assignment, TreatD x Post, are negative and statistically significant at the usual 5% level.
Notes: Study scope: The Vietnamese competitive electricity rebate program was first implemented in 2010 by Vietname Electricity. The program rollout by district power companies is not universal however all districts intend eventually to implement the program as they must adhere to the general instructions and requests from EVN that mandate the initiation of the program at some point.
Notes_interventionDuration: The primary dataset is a monthly household-level panel of electricity billing records from over 650000 residential customers for 72 months from Jan 2012 to Dec 2017
Notes_interventionType: To be eligible for the cash rebate, a HH must enroll and then reduce its monthly electricity consumption by at least 10% for a specified number of consecutive months of the program. Power companies promote the program through a variety of sources before the program starts - they advertise it on the mass media, distribute information leaflets, and provide guidelines on saving electricity. they conduct training courses on electricity savings to volunteer advocates and coordinate with local authorities to advertise the program at community meetings.

Notes: Sample size: The author hasn't provided the clear number of the HHs but has this information: the primary dataset is panel data of monthly electricity billing records from 27 district service territories from Jan 2012 to Dec 2017.
Notes: Doc level: The objective of the study is to investigate the efficacy of an electricity conservation contest that awards prizes to HHs for surpassing a minimum conservation requirement. Participation in the contest was voluntary but it was only available in certain districts at different times. The author assumes that conditional on the inclusion of HH-time fixed effects and controls for time-variant district characteristics, the timing of the contest roll-out was plausibly exogenous
Notes: Significance: The paper reports that the estimated coefficients for the post-treatment assignment, TreatD x Post, are negative and statistically significant at the usual 5% level.
Notes: Study scope: The Vietnamese competitive electricity rebate program was first implemented in 2010 by Vietname Electricity. The program rollout by district power companies is not universal however all districts intend eventually to implement the program as they must adhere to the general instructions and requests from EVN that mandate the initiation of the program at some point.
Notes_interventionDuration: The primary dataset is a monthly household-level panel of electricity billing records from over 650000 residential customers for 72 months from Jan 2012 to Dec 2017
Notes_interventionType: To be eligible for the cash rebate, a HH must enroll and then reduce its monthly electricity consumption by at least 10% for a specified number of consecutive months of the program. Power companies promote the program through a variety of sources before the program starts - they advertise it on the mass media, distribute information leaflets, and provide guidelines on saving electricity. they conduct training courses on electricity savings to volunteer advocates and coordinate with local authorities to advertise the program at community meetings.

Authors: Zhu, Jiaolan; Li, Jie; Liu, Ping; Shang, Yongtao; Ding, Zhikun; Alam, Md Morshed
document title: Effects of mixed normative feedback strategies on residents' energy conservation in shared spaces
abstract: Normative feedback has been shown to be effective in reducing energy use, but its impact is often temporary rather than sustained. To address this issue, mixed normative feedback strategies have been proposed as a potential solution for achieving more effective and lasting energy savings. However, the effectiveness of these strategies can vary significantly depending on the combinatory choices and social contexts in which they are implemented. Despite the potential benefits of mixed normative feedback strategies, it is currently unclear which mixed normative feedback strategies can effectively and sustainably promote energy conservation among residents in shared spaces. To address this gap, this study designed three mixed normative feedback strategies and conducted a 28-week field-controlled experiment to assess their effectiveness in motivating residents in shared dorms to save electricity. The Difference-in-Difference analysis was employed to evaluate their effectiveness. The results showed that the strategy mixing normative feedback with group-contrast feedback exhibited the greatest energy savings, with an average of 12.93 % after 5 weeks and 8.75 % after 12 weeks. The strategy combining normative feedback and instruction-based information failed to generate significant energy savings in the short term, but the inclusion of self-contrast feedback resulted in a significant 7.73 % reduction in energy consumption. Compared with single normative feedback, the mixed normative feedback strategies exhibited a more sustained energy savings after they were withdrawn. However, the sustained energy-saving effect was also found to decrease over time but at a slower rate than the single normative feedback. Therefore, further investigation is necessary to ensure long-term energy savings. These findings provide valuable insights and recommendations on how to use mixed normative feedback strategies to motivate residents to conserve energy in shared spaces, including the need to consider combinatory choices, intervention duration, and social contexts.
Notes: Coefficient: The dependent variable is energy. This is the regression result of the experimental group A and control group during the 1-9th week, with 1-4th week as the baseline period and 5-9 weeks as the intervention period. This coefficients suggests that there is an average of 12.93% energy savings because of the intervention.
Notes_baselineConsumption: Although there is a baseline period in the intervention but the details on the baseline consumption is provided on the weekly basis and not on the whole basis.
Notes: Sample size: In the beginning, 90 dorms were included in the experiment but 18 dorms withdrew in the beginning at the start of the experiment for various reasosns. The remaining 72 shared dorms which included 288 participants were randomly divided into three groups - two experimental groups and one control group with 24 dorms in each group.
Notes: Study scope: The experiment was conducted at university shared residences in Zhuhai, China which has a total of 31 shared residences including over 200 similar shared dorms with four occupants per dorm.
Notes_interventionDuration: The experiment consisted of three periods: a 4-week baseline period, a 12-week intervention period, and 11-week post-intervention period.
Notes_interventionType: The intervention period consisted of two phases: The experimental group A was given the coupled normative feedback with group-contrast feedback information during the two phases. Experimental group B was given a combination of normative feedback and instruction-based information in the first phase and self-contrast feedback was added into the second phase. No intervention was provided to the control group. During the post-intervention period, the interventions were withdrawn and the energy consumption of each room was continuously recorded for 11 weeks.

Authors: Singhal, Pooja
document title: Inform me when it matters: Cost salience, energy consumption, and efficiency investments
abstract: Using a large-scale natural experiment in staggered billing dates for energy use in Germany and a unique billing dataset for multi-apartment buildings, this paper shows that the month of billing is a significant determinant of heat energy consumption. A large set of residential buildings demand significantly more heat energy annually, when the bill is issued during off winter months. The paper finds evidence for salience cycles of heating bills that last up to 4 months, likely because consumer attention to heat energy costs is short-lived and absent during months when heating is off. Importantly, this phenomena is pervasive enough to be detectable even in aggregated building-level consumption data. Results suggest that the mere knowledge of costs is not sufficient and that the response to billing information also hinges on its time varying salience. These findings underscore the importance of understanding the dynamic and heterogeneous nature of cost salience in the design of effective billing for energy conservation.
Notes: Coefficient: The dependent variable is natural log of annual energy units consumed (kWh) per sqm for space heating by building i during the billing period that started in year t.
Notes_baselineConsumption: The author is trying to quantify the salience bias in annual heat demand and for that purpose she has the sample of buildings that likely receive their bills during the summer months (April to August) as the treatment group and buildings that are billed for the calendar year (Jan to Dec) as the control group. There is month-wise info on avg consumption but no baseline consumption info as such.
Notes: Sample size: The author reports that the sample for estimation comprises 152,025 buildings.
Notes: Doc level: This paper tests whether buildings billed in peak demand winter months are more responsive to bills than those billed in low demand summer months. To do so, the paper uses large panel data on heating bills from Jan 2008 to June 2018 from centrally heated, residential, multi-apartment buildings in Germany.
Notes: Study scope: The paper uses large panel data on heating bills from centrally heated, residential, multi-apartment buildings in Germany with close to comprehensive coverage - 7830 postal codes in all sixteen states of Germany.
Notes_interventionDuration: The paper uses large panel data on heating bills starting from Jan 2008 to June 2018. The buildings in the treatment group are the ones that likely receive their bills during the summer months (April to Aug) and buildings that are billed for the calendar year (Jan to Dec) are in the control group
Notes_interventionType: The intervention group was the buildings that receive their bills during the summer months (April to August)

Authors: Cellina, Francesca; Piero, Fraternali; Gonzalez, Sergio Luis Herrera; Novak, Jasminko; Gui, Marco; Rizzoli, Andrea Emilio
document title: Significant but transient: the impact of an energy saving app targeting Swiss households
abstract: In Global North countries, persuasive apps supporting households in reducing their energy consumption are widespread, as promising policy tools for the energy and climate transition. Despite their growing diffusion, fed by the large-scale smart meter roll-out currently ongoing in many energy systems, rigorous studies providing evidence on their effects are still missing, especially for the long-term. We address this research gap by analysing a one-year long app based electricity saving intervention performed in Switzerland between 2018 and 2019, involving 55 self-selected households. Adopting a quasi-experimental approach and considering four full years of energy consumption data, we estimate the app’s average treatment effect over time and perform heterogeneity analyses on household sub-groups, on varying their characteristics and intensity of app use. The app reduced consumption and CO2 emissions during the intervention (average treatment effect on the treated equal to 4.95%, statistically significant at the 0.05 level; Cohen’s d effect size equal to 0.35). However, one year later the effect disappeared. Our results put policies based on persuasive app use into perspective: taken in isolation, persuasive apps may exhibit limitations regarding long-lasting effects. To avoid relapse, future interventions might embed app use into broader processes explicitly aimed at redefining shared norms and conventions on household energy consumption practices, for instance within living lab processes.
dependent_variable: Logged Electricity Consumption of HH i at time t
Notes: Coefficient: This estimate represents the estimated difference between treatment and control households in the average change of electricity consumption between the intervention year and the reference year zero.
Notes: Sample size: The sample size for this model is taken from table 7 where the authors have provided the detailed estimate based on the same model
Notes: Doc level: The authors haven't provided the mean and SD for treatment and control groups separately.
Notes: Study scope: The intervention was located in the Italian-speaking part of Switzerland, in the small village of Contone (about 800 inhabitants, near the city of Locarno) and the treatment took place for one full year, from June, 1 2018 to May, 31 2019.
Notes_interventionDuration: The treatment took place for a full year from June 1 2018 to May 31 2019. And the authors  analyse the data for one pre-intervention year, the intervention year, and two post-intervention years making the total intervention to four years.
Notes_interventionType: The treated households were provided with the enCompass app and were invited to freely use it during the one-year intervention period, with no specific requirements on the minimum amount of interactions they should perform. The key features offered by the enCompass app consist in the provision of feedback on energy consumption and its impacts, in setting a customised goal for change, in receiving tips supporting such a change, and in getting rewards, in a gamification approach

Despite their growing diffusion, fed by the large-scale smart meter roll-out currently ongoing in many energy systems, rigorous studies providing evidence on their effects are still missing, especially for the long-term. We address this research gap by analysing a one-year long app based electricity saving intervention performed in Switzerland between 2018 and 2019, involving 55 self-selected households. Adopting a quasi-experimental approach and considering four full years of energy consumption data, we estimate the app’s average treatment effect over time and perform heterogeneity analyses on household sub-groups, on varying their characteristics and intensity of app use. The app reduced consumption and CO2 emissions during the intervention (average treatment effect on the treated equal to 4.95%, statistically significant at the 0.05 level; Cohen’s d effect size equal to 0.35). However, one year later the effect disappeared. Our results put policies based on persuasive app use into perspective: taken in isolation, persuasive apps may exhibit limitations regarding long-lasting effects. To avoid relapse, future interventions might embed app use into broader processes explicitly aimed at redefining shared norms and conventions on household energy consumption practices, for instance within living lab processes.
dependent_variable: Logged Electricity Consumption of HH i at time t
Notes: Coefficient: This estimate represents the estimated difference between treatment and control households in the average change of electricity consumption between the year three after the intervention and the reference year zero.
Notes: Sample size: The sample size for this model is taken from table 7 where the authors have provided the detailed estimate based on the same model
Notes: Doc level: The authors haven't provided the mean and SD for treatment and control groups separately.
Notes: Study scope: The intervention was located in the Italian-speaking part of Switzerland, in the small village of Contone (about 800 inhabitants, near the city of Locarno) and the treatment took place for one full year, from June, 1 2018 to May, 31 2019.
Notes_interventionDuration: The treatment took place for a full year from June 1 2018 to May 31 2019. And the authors  analyse the data for one pre-intervention year, the intervention year, and two post-intervention years making the total intervention to four years.
Notes_interventionType: The treated households were provided with the enCompass app and were invited to freely use it during the one-year intervention period, with no specific requirements on the minimum amount of interactions they should perform. The key features offered by the enCompass app consist in the provision of feedback on energy consumption and its impacts, in setting a customised goal for change, in receiving tips supporting such a change, and in getting rewards, in a gamification approach

Authors: Ayertey, Winfred; Sharifi, Ayyoob; Yoshida, Yuichiro
document title: The impact of increase in block pricing on electricity demand responsiveness: Evidence from Ghana
abstract: The implementation of Increase in Block Pricing (IBP) policy is premised on the assumption that consumers adjust their behavior to save energy in response to electricity price increases. However, consumers often lack a comprehensive understanding of the pricing schedules, leading to inaccurate consumption predictions. This study utilizes monthly electricity billing data from the administrative records of urban residential consumers of the Electricity Company of Ghana Limited to estimate the causal effect of IBP policy schedules on electricity consumption. To achieve this, we employed the Regression Kink (RK) design identification strategy to explore the kink structure of the policy function. This paper finds an inelastic causal relationship between IBP policy and electricity consumption. The results show a treatment effect of 0.41 KWh with an associated p-value of 0.473 at a robust 95 % confidence interval. Thus, IBP policy has no causal effect on electricity consumption at the 50 KWh lower block threshold. Notably, electricity consumers do not respond significantly to price increments, rendering IBP policy ineffective in achieving energy saving at the lower block threshold. This research contributes to a deeper understanding of the effectiveness of IBP policy in promoting energy savings and informs researchers, policymakers, and stakeholders in the energy sector. Results can be used to develop evidence-based policies that contribute to energy conservation and climate change mitigation.
Notes: Coefficient: This is the baseline estimates where the effect is the Regression Kink estimate of the average treatment effect of IBP policy on the outcome (next month's electricity consumption)
Notes: Sample size: The authors have not provided the sample sizes differently for the groups and the numbers have been taken from Table 3 where they have reported the effective number of control and treatment consumers
Notes: Doc level: The authors haven't provided the mean and SD for treatment and control group separately. However they have provided the summary statistics in Table 2 which has information on the variables used in the equation
Notes: Study scope: The study's objective is to evaluate the effect of the Ghana's IBP policy on the residential consumers.
Notes_interventionDuration: The administrative dataset contains information on the monthly electricity consumption of households in four districts from 2010 to 2015
Notes_interventionType: The treatment was the IBP policy schedule. The unit of analysis is the individual urban household customer of the electricity company of Ghana. This study focuses on the 50KWh threshold meaning the analysis was restricted to customers whose consumption was just below and above the 50KWh threshold.

Authors: Nguyen, Nhu Ngoc; Goto, Daisaku; Tran, Duc; Vu, Ha Thu
document title: Nudging households to save electricity with feedback: Experimental evidence from Vietnam
abstract: Information feedback based on the real-time records of smart meters has shown the potential to nudge residential electricity conservation in developed countries. However, evidence on this topic in developing countries is scarce and limited in scale. This paper provides new experimental evidence regarding how information feedback affects household electricity consumption in Vietnam, a developing country in Southeast Asia. By conducting a randomized controlled trial involving 1,028 households in Da Nang city, we show that three types of feedback â€“ self-comparison, social comparison, and goal setting â€“ can help households reduce their daily electricity consumption 4.1â€“6.7%. We explore the heterogeneous effects and find that social comparison exhibits discernible heterogeneity depending on the day of the week. Social comparison is also effective for both low and high quantiles of electricity consumers, whereas self-comparison and goal setting are effective mainly for the latter. We discuss the implications of our empirical findings for policies related to using feedback to nudge household electricity conservation. Â© 2024 Elsevier Ltd
Notes: Coefficient: This is the ATT estimates using the DID approach on T1 - Self-comparison without any control
Notes: Difference of means: The authors have provided the mean and standard deviation for the control group. However for the treatment groups they have reported the mean differences between the control group and the treatment group and the standard errors pertaining to the mean differences and not the standard deviations for the treatment groups.
Notes: Sample size: There is one control group with 254 HHs and three treatment groups with 258 HHs each
Notes: Study scope: The field experiment was conducted in seven inland districts of Da Nang city, Vietnam
Notes_interventionDuration: From 26 Aug 2022 to 26 Sept 2022, the authors did the stratified sampling of housholds, obtaining consent by phone calls and stratified randomization of experimental groups and then for the last 8 weeks until Nov 20, 2022, they implemented the field experiment of feedback provision via SMS
Notes_interventionType: The treatment was the self-comparison - comparison of consumption in the previous week to that in the week before the previous week

Authors: Alberini, Anna; Bezhanishvili, Levan; Scasny, Milan
document title: Heterogeneous effects of government energy assistance programs: Covid-19 lockdowns in the republic of Georgia
abstract: During the Covid-19 pandemic, the governments of many countries adopted measures to support the population during the lockdowns and periods of reduced economic activity. In the Republic of Georgia, in April 2020 the government announced that it would pay the electricity bills of residential customers in April and May 2020, effectively making electricity free, as long as usage would not exceed 200 kWh/month. Consumers using more than 200 kWh would pay the regular tariff on the entire consumption (not just the kWh above 200). In August 2020, the government announced that the policy would be in force again in November and December 2020, and January and February 2021. We examine meter readings from a 10 % sample of the country's customers base outside of the Tbilisi city limits to see if the response to the policy is consistent with the predictions from economic theory. We find that, as suggested by economic theory, in the months when the policy is in place low-volume consumers increase their electricity usage and high-volume consumers decrease it in an effort to make the 200 kWh mark. However, we do not find any evidence of â€œbunchingâ€ at 200 kWh or of a â€œholeâ€ thereafter. The average household increased usage by some 5 % above and beyond their normal. This figure however masks considerable heterogeneity in the effects of the policy across urban, rural, and â€œhigh mountainâ€ status areas. Â© 2024 Elsevier B.V.
Notes: Coefficient: This is the model of log elec consumption controlling for weather, regional patterns, and hh-by-month effects
Notes: Difference of means: In Table 1 of the paper, the authors have provided the descriptive stats of elec consumption by region for pre-prndemic, free elec months and post pandemic without free elec months.
Notes: Sample size: There is no control and treatment groups here and the  sample is 10% of the EPG customer base, covers Jan. 2017 to Sept. 2021, and excludes observations below 31 and above 1000 kWh per month. For this effect size the total sample is 96824 as mentioned in Table 3
Notes: Study scope: The authors focused on the service territory of Energo-Pro Georgia which is essentially the entire country outside of the Tbilisi city limits except for the autonomous regions of Abkhazia and South Ossetia.
Notes_interventionDuration: The period of analysis is Jan 2017 to Spet 2021 and in Georgia the electricity was free for 4 months in 2020 (April, May, November, December) and 2 months in 2021 (January and February).
Notes_interventionType: The policy intervention tested in this paper is the effect of free electricity months

Authors: Garcia, Alexandre Schwinden; Alves, Frederick Fagundes; Filgueiras, Joao Marcello Pimentel
document title: Tariff flags and electricity consumption response in Brazil
abstract: We evaluated the effectiveness of the tariff flags system (TFS) on electricity consumption in Brazil. Tariff flags represent a demand-side management (DSM) mechanism used in the Brazilian electricity sector and act as a signal sent to agents about electricity production costs. The effectiveness of the flags in reducing electricity consumption is assessed using monthly consumption data from 26 Brazilian states between 2015 and 2022, and panel data models with fixed effects were estimated. The results indicate that only the water scarcity flag effectively reduced electricity consumption by 2.89%. When the Yellow, Red I, and Red II flags were in operation, there was a median increase in electricity consumption of 0.61%, 4.24%, and 1.47%, respectively. In addition, the other variables indicate that the higher the temperature and income of the States, the higher the consumption, and the higher the electricity tariff, the lower the consumption. We also observed persistence in the consumption of electricity in the States, possibly related to consumer habits. Â© 2024 Elsevier Ltd
Notes: Coefficient: Here the depedent variable is the logarithm of per capita electricity consumption and this is coefficient of the panel data fiexed effects model for Yellow Flag when there is less favourable power generation conditons
Notes: Difference of means: In table 3 of the paper, the authors have provided the descriptive statistics on all the variables but there is no difference of means since this is a panel data model
Notes: Sample size: There is no clear description on the sample size in the paper. This is what they mention - As for the dependent variable (lnEConsi,t), the data provide aggregate consumption for the entire State. We divide consumption by the number of consumer units in each State to obtain the average consumption of electricity per capita. An electricity consumer unit is a location where electricity is used, identified by a unique number provided by the electricity distributor in each Brazilian State. Typically, it is connected to the electrical grid through a meter that records electricity consumption. The electricity bill is calculated based on this recorded consumption.
Notes: Study scope: This is what the authors mentioned - Given the objective of this work, we used the variable that seeks to be explained, the consumption of electrical energy monthly from April 2015 to May 2022 (86 months) of the 25 largest distributors in the Brazilian States plus the Federal District. We chose to remove the State of Roraima, as it is not connected to the National Interconnected System and, consequently, is not part of the Tariff Flag Methodology.
Notes_interventionDuration: The period of data is from April 2015 to May 2022 and the duration in months in which the yellow flag was in effect was 16 months
Notes_interventionType: In this paper the authors aim to to evaluate the effectiveness of tariff flags in reducing electricity consumption in Brazilian States. The results shed light on the DSM policy implemented in the Brazilian electricity sector.

Notes: Coefficient: Here the depedent variable is the logarithm of per capita electricity consumption and this is coefficient of the panel data fiexed effects model for Scarcity Flag when there is extreme cost power generation conditons
Notes: Difference of means: In table 3 of the paper, the authors have provided the descriptive statistics on all the variables but there is no difference of means since this is a panel data model
Notes: Sample size: There is no clear description on the sample size in the paper. This is what they mention - As for the dependent variable (lnEConsi,t), the data provide aggregate consumption for the entire State. We divide consumption by the number of consumer units in each State to obtain the average consumption of electricity per capita. An electricity consumer unit is a location where electricity is used, identified by a unique number provided by the electricity distributor in each Brazilian State. Typically, it is connected to the electrical grid through a meter that records electricity consumption. The electricity bill is calculated based on this recorded consumption.
Notes: Study scope: This is what the authors mentioned - Given the objective of this work, we used the variable that seeks to be explained, the consumption of electrical energy monthly from April 2015 to May 2022 (86 months) of the 25 largest distributors in the Brazilian States plus the Federal District. We chose to remove the State of Roraima, as it is not connected to the National Interconnected System and, consequently, is not part of the Tariff Flag Methodology.
Notes_interventionDuration: The period of data is from April 2015 to May 2022 and the duration in months in which the scarcity flag was in effect was 8 months
Notes_interventionType: In this paper the authors aim to to evaluate the effectiveness of tariff flags in reducing electricity consumption in Brazilian States. The results shed light on the DSM policy implemented in the Brazilian electricity sector.

Authors: Cellina, Francesca; Gerosa, Tiziano; Granato, Pasquale; Lobsiger-Kagi, Evelyn; Wemyss, Devon; Kienast, Pascal
document title: Can app-based communities support energy sufficiency in households? Evidence from a one-year quasi-experiment in Switzerland
abstract: App-based interventions are increasingly used to foster energy-sufficient household routines. Previous studies rarely measure whether the effect persists in the long-term, and for the few that have, the savings effects â€“ often estimated without a control group â€“ are not maintained over time. To favour long-lasting effects, we posit that (i) app users should be engaged in the app design, (ii) apps should focus on collective-level features that support community building (rather than individual-level consumption feedback only), and (iii) specific app features are needed in the long-term to resist relapse. We assess the overall effect of these strategies in the â€œSocial Power Plus Community Energy Challengeâ€, an app-based intervention run in 2022 in Switzerland involving about 200 voluntary households. Quasi-experimental estimates under a weighted Difference-in-Differences approach show that on average the intervention produced nearly 5% energy savings over one full year. However, the effect was higher in the first quarter (up to 11% energy saving), becoming negligible in the last quarters. We reflect on how the three strategies did not ensure long-term effects and recommend future research to further explore the potential of community-based processes, focusing less on apps and more on collectively questioning dominant social norms around household routines. Â© 2024 The Author(s)
Notes: Coefficient: This is the ATT estimate of the SPP CEC treatment effect on the treated by considering energy consumption in years 2021 and 2020 as baseline outcome levels
Notes: Difference of means: The authors haven't shared the mean and std dev for both the treatment and control group here.
Notes: Sample size: The sample size bifurcation is available in Table 2
Notes: Study scope: The SPP CEC test took place in collaboration with regional energy providers from 1st February 2022 to 31st December 2022 in three distinct Swiss regions: rural Schaffhausen (SCH), small-town Wil (WIL), and urban Winterthur (WIN).
Notes_interventionDuration: The study has a baselin pretest period which spans from Jan 2020 to Jan 2022 and then the posttest period which spans from Jan 2022 to Jan 2023. The SPP CEC program ran in two phases - high intensity from Feb 2022 to May 2022 and low intensity from May 2022 to Jan 2023.
Notes_interventionType: The SPP CEC intervention - Social Powe Plus Community Energy Challenge is an app based intervention that targetted energy sufficient HH and has features at two level - individual HH level and community level. The features include Goal setting, feedback, sufficiency challenges, tips, reminders, pinboard, regional energy saving competitions, and monthly live meetings

Authors: Kirchler, Benjamin; Kollmann, Andrea; Sinea, Anca; Volintiru, Clara
document title: Behavioural insights into energy consumption in times of crisis
abstract: We study the impact of four different information framing methods on household energy consumption among 30,000 households in Romania. In a field experiment, households were randomly allocated to either the control group or one of four experimental groups. The framing of the mail focused on different benefits: i) individual economic benefits, ii) environmental benefits, iii) individual health framing, and iv) community health framing. Using a difference-in-difference approach, we show that tailored information interventions significantly influence household energy consumption behaviours. The results indicate that the overall treatment effect led to a significant 1.5 % reduction in electricity consumption compared to the control group. Treated households reduced their electricity consumption by 48 kWh annually, resulting in total savings in the treatment group of approx. 718 MWh/year. Among the specific treatments, the â€œIndividual Healthâ€ and â€œCollective Healthâ€ interventions showed the most substantial impact. The â€œIndividual Healthâ€ treatment resulted in a 2.9 % reduction, while the â€œCollective Healthâ€ treatment achieved a 4.3 % reduction in electricity consumption. These results highlight the effectiveness of health-related messaging in promoting energy conservation. Â© 2024
Notes: Coefficient: This is the coefficient for the interaction term Post-treatment*Treatment General which represents the DiD estimator after controlling for time fixed effects and individual fixed effects. Here the authors comibine the four treatments and test if mailing has an effect.
Notes: Difference of means: The authors haven't shared the mean and std dev for both the treatment and control group here.
Notes: Study scope: The field experiment was conducted with the support of the largest energy supplier in Romania, Electrical Furnizare SA and targeted a large sample of Romanian HHs
Notes_interventionDuration: The total duration includes the timeframe from Jan 2020 to Dec 2022. However the authors mentioned that intervention was delivered via email in three separate monthly mailings on 20th April, 4th May and 8th June 2022.
Notes_interventionType: In this paper, based on the previous literature and a survey, the authors developed four types of interventions to inform HHs about (1) possible financial gains related to consumption reduction through an 'individual benefit intervention', (2)  environmental impacts formulated in an altruistic social norm intervention through an “altruism and social norm intervention”;  and (3) individual and (4) collective health impacts through an “individual” and “collective information intervention”.

Authors: Curley, Cali; Xu, Corey Keiwei; Orlove, Ben; Forster, Hale; Harrison, Nicky
document title: Influence of messaging and party affiliation on energy conservation behavior: An evaluation from the US
abstract: Governments have numerous avenues available to them to leverage energy consumption reductions. Low-cost policy options may be as simple as incorporating information related to energy consumption reduction. Despite the viability of these low-cost options, there is little understanding of how individual characteristics influence the viability of messaging strategies. This study fills the research gap by investigating how residents' political affiliation may affect their response to utility messaging for reducing energy consumption. We use the City of Tallahassee, Florida, as a testbed to investigate how informational messages alter customers' energy consumption behavior. We examined the effects of monthly messages on a random sample of 3000 households from 2011 to 2015. Our analysis reveals that pro-environmental and cost savings frames result in different levels of energy conservation according to political affiliation. This study helps resolve previous studies' inconsistent findings by expanding the information analysis to fine-scale data observed in actual energy consumption behavior. For practitioners, our results shed new light on how to effectively alter customers' energy conservation behavior through messaging by strategically accounting for the characteristics of customers.
Notes: Coefficient: This is coefficient for effects of messaging on energy consumption - utility programming energy tips
Notes: Difference of means: The authors have only shared the mean differences for republican and democratic residents and not any pre-post bifurcation.
Notes: Sample size: The authors have not clearly provided the bifurcation of sample of HHs per type of messaging
Notes: Doc level: The authors have not clarified clearly the information on standard errors
Notes: Uncertainty: The R-squared and adjusted R-squared values are quite low (0.268 each)
Notes: Study scope: The paper focuses on the City of Tallahassee in the state of Florida
Notes_interventionDuration: The authors have not provided a clear description of the timeframe -  We utilize a mid-sized city in the United States(US) as a test case, focusing on coding the language within newsletters shared by the city during 2011–2015.
medium: Insight newsletters shared with the public
Notes_interventionType: In this paper, the authors take two-step approch to study the effect - first step is to conduct content analysis by coding the monthly Insight newsletters shared with the public. This coding provides insight into the types of messaging present in the newsletters. They then develop a database from multiple sources that incorporates monthly energy consumption, household characteristics, voter registration information, and census block characteristics. This results in a comprehensive panel dataset that includes multiple sources.

Authors: Fang, Zheng; Le, Thai-Ha; Yu, Jiang; Fan, Manyi
document title: Evaluating Causal Effects of Increasing Block Pricing Policy on Residential Electricity Consumption in China
abstract: Using two waves of the China Family Panel Studies (CFPS), a nationally representative longitudinal household-level survey, this paper investigates how residential electricity consumption is affected by the increasing block pricing (IBP) policy nationwide. The results from the difference-in-differences approach suggest that the IBP policy is effective in reducing households' electricity consumption, and the reduction size is about 43 and 120 kWh for households affected by the second and third block pricing, respectively. Compared to rural households, urban households are found to be less impacted by the IBP policy. Besides, there are heterogeneous effects across various income groups, though the trend of the treatment effects is inconsistent. The findings are proved to be robust to different study samples and different model specifications.
Notes: Coefficient: This is the coefficient estimate for the treatment on Tier 2 without any control variables
Notes: Difference of means: The authors do have provided the summary statistics and the distribution of avergae monthly electricity consumption across the two years and the three tiers but there is no standard reporting of the mean and standard deviations.
Notes: Sample size: The authors haven't provided the sample size tier-wise clearly. They do have provided the total number of HHs in the data
Notes: Study scope: In this paper, the data used in this study are taken from the CFPS, a nationally representative longitudinal survey. The baseline survey was  launched in 2010, covering about 15,000 families and 30,000 individuals across 25 provinces in China.
Notes_interventionDuration: The authors have not provided a clear description of the intervention duration - for 2012 they have used data from July-Oct but they have not provided the same information for 2014. Here I have assumed the same number of days for 2014 as in 2012.
Notes_interventionType: In this paper, the authors use CFPS 2012 and CFPS 2014 to investigate the causal effect of the IBP policy implemented nationwide in July 2012 on household electricity consumption.

Authors: Dertwinkel-Kalt, Markus; Feldhaus, Christoph; Ockenfels, Axel; Sutter, Matthias
document title: Household reduction of gas consumption in the energy crisis is not explained by individual economic incentives
abstract: In response to the disruption of gas supplies from Russia following the invasion of Ukraine in 2022, European politicians and public utilities appealed to citizens and customers to conserve natural gas. Moreover, they strengthened economic incentives for gas conservation. In fact, a substantial amount of natural gas was saved during the winter of 2022/23. This raises the question to what extent this success is attributable to government and corporate means to foster energy conservation in the crisis, including energy policies such as the German governmentâ€™s â€œgas price brake,â€ gas-saving programs launched by public utilities, and consumersâ€™ individual pricing schemes. We analyzed the effectiveness of these means using a survey and a field experiment with a German gas supplier and show that, while household savings during the crisis were substantial, economic incentives did not significantly change behavior. Indeed, demand for gas is largely price inelastic. A large majority of consumers do not understand the incentives arising from the gas price brake, and when they do, they do not respond. Likewise, consumers do not react to the design of the utilitiesâ€™ gas-saving program. These findings suggest that i) citizensâ€™ response to marginal individual economic incentives contributes little to overall gas savings, and ii) the crisis, along with the extensive societal engagement it generated, likely shifted the publicâ€™s mindset about energy consumption, making conservation a social priority. Copyright Â© 2024 the Author(s).
Notes: Coefficient: This is the coefficient from the first model for testing the effect of gas-saving goals
Notes: Difference of means: The authors have provided the mean and sd consumption levels for both the suvery and field experiments HHs in the supplementary tables
Notes: Sample size: For this specific effect size, the authors used the sample from survey experiment as the control group and the sample from the field experiment as the treatment group. I have reported the same number in the case of sample size since they haven't provided a clear information on the number.
Notes: Doc level: There are different things that have been tested out in this paper and here I have included the one where they tested the effect of a saving program on gas consumption.
Notes: Significance: The authors have not provided a clear picture of the significance levels. The same goes for the standard errors. The tables are not descriptive enough
Notes: Study scope: The paper have two components - a survey experiment and a field experiment - the field experiment is restricted to the region around Wuppertal and lasts until April, while the survey experiment encompasses all of Germany and ends already in March.
Notes_Biases: To investigate the effect of saving program on gas consumption, the authors designated survey experiment sample as a control group against the field experiment sample. Notably, the survey experiment was not designed to serve as a control group for the field experiment, so this control group has some limitations
Notes_interventionDuration: The survey experiment was conducted in two rounds - Dec 20, 2022 to Jan 11 2023 and another from Feb 28 to March 14 2023. And the field experiment was conducted between Jan 15 2023 and April 15 2023
Notes_interventionType: In this paper, the authors took advantage of a gas-saving program that the provider implemented for its customers. Through the program, it was determined that a monetary bonus of either 50 EUR or 100 EUR, depending on the household’s previous year consumption level, is paid for customers who reach a specified savings goal. The savings goal was experimentally varied, set at either 10% or 20% of the household’s consumption level in the previous year.

Authors: Dertwinkel-Kalt, Markus; Feldhaus, Christoph; Ockenfels, Axel; Sutter, Matthias
document title: Household reduction of gas consumption in the energy crisis is not explained by individual economic incentives
abstract: In response to the disruption of gas supplies from Russia following the invasion of Ukraine in 2022, European politicians and public utilities appealed to citizens and customers to conserve natural gas. Moreover, they strengthened economic incentives for gas conservation. In fact, a substantial amount of natural gas was saved during the winter of 2022/23. This raises the question to what extent this success is attributable to government and corporate means to foster energy conservation in the crisis, including energy policies such as the German governmentâ€™s â€œgas price brake,â€ gas-saving programs launched by public utilities, and consumersâ€™ individual pricing schemes. We analyzed the effectiveness of these means using a survey and a field experiment with a German gas supplier and show that, while household savings during the crisis were substantial, economic incentives did not significantly change behavior. Indeed, demand for gas is largely price inelastic. A large majority of consumers do not understand the incentives arising from the gas price brake, and when they do, they do not respond. Likewise, consumers do not react to the design of the utilitiesâ€™ gas-saving program. These findings suggest that i) citizensâ€™ response to marginal individual economic incentives contributes little to overall gas savings, and ii) the crisis, along with the extensive societal engagement it generated, likely shifted the publicâ€™s mindset about energy consumption, making conservation a social priority. Authors: Qin, Botao; Xie, Siyuan; Xu, Chenyang
document title: Social recognition, goal setting, and energy conservation: Evidence from a field experiment in student dormitories
abstract: Non-monetary incentives are increasingly being studied in encouraging energy conservation. In light of this, we conducted a natural field experiment in student dormitories to assess the effect of social recognition and goal setting on electricity saving and the intrinsic motivation to save energy. Using a difference-in-difference model, we found that goal setting reduced the dormitoriesâ€™ electricity consumption by 15.93% on average compared to the control group. However, social recognition was not effective on average. In addition, the study found that both social recognition and goal setting, on average, did not crowd out or crowd in the intrinsic motivation to save electricity in dormitories. The heterogeneity analysis showed that dormitory characteristics affect the crowding effect on the intrinsic motivation. Â© 2024 Elsevier Ltd
Notes: Coefficient: This is the effect size for the social recognition treatment during the second stage i.e the treatment stage
Notes: Difference of means: The authors have not provided the mean and sd for the control and treatment groups separately. They have provided week-wise mean and median electricity consumption in the first stage.
Notes: Sample size: The authors have provided the number of dormitories for both the control and treatment groups. They have also provided the estimates on number of students in each dormitory.
Notes: Uncertainty: One important things to note is that the choice of treatment group is not random and a building was chosen as the treatment group because it had enough dorms so that a large sample size for each treatment group can be established.
Notes: Study scope: The experiment was done at the campus of Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an, China.
Notes_Biases: The authors note these important points - the choice of treatment group is not random; all student residents in the buildings are male
Notes_interventionDuration: The experiment lasted 12 weeks and was divided into three stages (4 weeks for each stage). The first stage (the pre-treatment stage) ran from October 1st to October 31st and there was no intervention. The second stage (the treatment stage) ran from November 1st to December 1st, during which the dormitories received their respective treatments. The last stage (the post-treatment stage) ran from February 13th to March 14th.
Notes_interventionType: In this paper, the authors conducted a natural field experiment in student dormitories to assess the effect of social recognition and goal setting on electricity saving and the intrinsic motivation to save energy. They ran the experiment at the campus of Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an, China and targeted four dormitory buildings on the campus

Authors: Wang, Yuan; Xu, Huayu; Xu, Xiaoguang; Zhou, Yongmei
document title: The power of children in energy conservation: Evidence from a randomized controlled trial
abstract: We conducted a randomized evaluation of an innovative energy conservation program in China, engaging students in electricity usage auditing and peer competitions. The results show a 7% reduction in household electricity consumption four months post-intervention, with more pronounced effects among younger students and families with lower educational backgrounds. This reduction is primarily attributed to improvements in studentsâ€™ daily consumption behaviors and knowledge of conservation strategies. Additionally, the program induced students to nudge their parents towards energy-saving practices, although these efforts did not translate into significant changes in parental behavior. If scaled nationwide, the program could potentially reduce residential electricity consumption by 2.5% and lower China's carbon emissions by 0.27%. Â© 2024 Elsevier B.V.
Notes: Coefficient: This is the coefficient for the treatment controlling for the strata-by-survey round fixed effects and class fixed effects to account for time-variant differences across schools and time-invariant differences across classes.
Notes_baselineConsumption: The authors have provided the baseline consumption details for both the treatment and control groups for pre and post treatment but in a graph
Notes: Difference of means: The authors haven't provided the means and sd of the treatment and control groups clearly in a table anywhere. Figure 1 has the information on Pre and post intervention electricity use by group
Notes: Sample size: Here I have reported the sample size in terms of the classes, that's how the authors have reported this number. However they also have informed that on an average each class had 43 students and the participants spanned from grades 2 to 8.
Notes: Doc level: The HHs numbers are not clear since the unit of randomization is at the class level
Notes: Study scope: The study involved students from 81 classes across 22 public schools in five Chinese cities: Beijing, Shanghai, Wuhan, Chengdu, and Luzhou.
city: Beijing, Shanghai, Wuhan, Chengdu, and Luzhou
Notes_interventionDuration: The program began in the last week of April 2023 and lasted for five weeks. Each week, students in the treatment group participated in a 45-minute classroom session, complemented by supplementary activities outside of class. The introductory phase, conducted in the first week, aimed to familiarize students with the program’s objectives, procedures, and key logistics.  In the second week, the focus shifted to conducting electricity usage audits in students’ homes.  The final three weeks were dedicated to the peer competition phase.
Notes_interventionType: In this paper, the authors examined a five-week conservation program designed to reduce household electricity consumption among primary and secondary school students in China. The program engaged students in two main activities - electricity usage auditing and peer competitions for energy savings.
